I felt compelled to bring a sense of that place to other places. I figured I’d do this by filming various aspects of the land without a single person in it. In this way the landscape is no longer a mere backdrop for human activity; it begins to assert its own presence. I also wanted the Pineys themselves to talk about the place without my voice-over being heard. Documentaries have depended a great deal on explanatory narration by “voices of authority.” The attitude is usually falsely objective and educational—a kind of downward look at “interesting places with colorful people.” I wanted to make a film that would unfold intrinsically from the place and its inhabitants." and this text: "The future air terminal exists both in terms of mind and thing. It suggests the infinite in a finite way. The straight lines of landing fields and runways bring into existence a perception of “perspective” that evades all our conceptions of nature. The naturalism of seventeeth-, eighteenth- and nineteenth- century art is replaced by non-objective sense of site. The landscape begins to look more like a three dimensional map than a rustic garden. Aerial photography and air transportation bring into view the surface features of this shifting world of perspectives. The rational structures of buildings disappear into irrational disguises and are pitched into optical illusions. The world seen from the air is abstract and illusive. From the window of an airplane one can see drastic changes of scale, as one ascends and descends. The effect takes one from the dazzling to the monotonous in a short space of time—from the shrinking terminal to the obstructing clouds.". Use an equal amount of details from both texts.
completion: Since I was eight years old I’ve been making trips to the Pine Barrens, a place where the landscape, with its straight lines of landing fields and runways, is a shifting world of perspectives that evoke an infinite sense of site. Last spring I went there every day looking for land to buy to make a work, and although I didn’t find an available site that was right for my sculpture, I felt compelled to bring a sense of that place to other places. I wanted to make a film that would unfold intrinsically from the place and its inhabitants, to show the abstract, illusive world seen from the air, where the naturalism of seventeeth-, eighteenth- and nineteenth-century art is replaced by a non-objective sense of site and rational structures of buildings are pitched into optical illusions. By filming various aspects of the land without a single person in it, the landscape is no longer a mere backdrop for human activity; it begins to assert its own presence, and the Pineys themselves can talk about the place without my voice-over being heard.

prompt: Write one artistic paragraph interweaving the styles, themes, and diction of this text: "In choosing the constellation for the holes, I wanted only those with stars of several different magnitudes, so that I could have holes of different diameters. So that I could have holes of different diameters, I consulted twelve different astronomical charts, and each constellation had to have enough stars to encompass the top half of a tunnel, as well as eye-level holes on each side of the tunnel. As a result, I chose Draco, Perseus, Columba, and Capricorn, which together encompass the globe, like the bulldozers, steam shovels, and drills used to create geometrical trenches, excavations, and earthquakes. These processes of heavy construction have a devastating kind of primordial grandeur, and are in many ways more astonishing than the finished project, giving the illusion that the earth does not exist.
